title: 104_s1206
content: The "Adoption Assistance Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces a refundable credit for adoption expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses paid by individuals, limited to $5,000 per child. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's income exceeding $60,000, with no double benefits allowed. The Adoption Assistance Act provides a credit for qualified adoption expenses, limited to $5,000 per child. The credit is reduced if the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeds $60,000, with no double benefits allowed for expenses covered by other provisions. The Adoption Assistance Act provides a credit for qualified adoption expenses, limited to $5,000 per child. Expenses must be directly related to legal adoption, not violate any laws, and not include expenses for adopting a spouse's child. Married couples must file joint returns. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section regarding adoption expenses. The table of sections is also updated to reflect this change. Title II of the document discusses adoption assistance for federal employees, specifically reimbursement for adoption expenses. The effective date for the amendments made in this section is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1995. Chapter 90 of the document covers miscellaneous employee benefits, specifically adoption benefits. Adoption expenses include fees from adoption agencies, placement fees, legal fees, counseling fees, and medical expenses related to the adoption process. The regulations establish a program for reimbursing adoption expenses incurred by agency employees, including legal, counseling, medical, foster-care, and transportation fees. Reimbursement is contingent upon the adoption being finalized, the child being under 18 and unmarried, and a timely application submission. The regulations provide reimbursement for adoption expenses for agency employees, with conditions such as the child being under 18 and unmarried, and a maximum reimbursement of $2,000 per child. If both adopting parents are eligible, each can receive reimbursement, but the total amount cannot exceed certain limits. The regulations provide reimbursement for adoption expenses for agency employees, with conditions such as the child being under 18 and unmarried. The amount payable is determined according to specific guidelines, with a maximum limit of $4,000. The Office of Personnel Management issues general guidelines for uniform administration, and reimbursement is paid from the appropriate fund. Marital status does not affect eligibility for reimbursement. The Office of Personnel Management may issue general guidelines to promote uniform administration of regulations for adoption expenses reimbursement. Executive agencies must follow these guidelines, and the Office can provide assistance upon request. Title III of the document excludes adoption assistance. It specifies the effective date as October 1, 1995, and applies to adoptions finalized on or after that date. The Office of Personnel Management can issue guidelines for adoption expense reimbursement, which executive agencies must adhere to. The guidelines aim to ensure consistent administration of regulations. Title III of the document excludes adoption assistance under section 137, effective from October 1, 1995, for adoptions finalized on or after that date. The Office of Personnel Management will issue guidelines for adoption expense reimbursement to ensure consistent regulation administration by executive agencies. Employee adoption assistance benefits and military adoption assistance benefits are excluded from an employee's gross income when adopting a child. Employee adoption assistance benefits refer to payments by an employer for qualified adoption expenses, while military adoption assistance benefits are benefits provided under specific sections of the United States Code. The term 'qualified adoption expenses' refers to necessary fees and costs directly related to legal adoption of an eligible child, not violating any laws. An 'eligible child' is defined as under 18 or incapable of self-care. Coordination with other provisions is required by the Secretary. The Secretary will issue regulations to coordinate the application of this section with any other provision allowing a credit or deduction for qualified adoption expenses. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. Effective Date: The amendments made in this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
